intro.text:
You are in an open area with tall, tough grass. Wood is scarce, but the wind carries seeds of esparto grass, oats, and rushes.

If you braid it well, you could make a rope over a meter long. Will it be enough to tie a spear or hang a load?

Can you braid long grass into a useful, strong rope?

options.label: Begin
options.successMsg: You start harvesting the longest and most flexible plants...

e1.text: 1. There are many long stems. Which ones do you choose?

options.label: Green, thin, elastic grass over 60 cm tall
options.successMsg: Perfect for torsion. Doesn't break when bent.

options.label: Dry, golden grass in the sun
options.failMsg: It breaks easily. Not suitable for heavy-duty rope.

options.label: Hard and thick reeds
options.failMsg: Very rigid. They cannot be bent or braided.

options.label: Grass crushed and rotten at the base
options.failMsg: It's wet and weak. It crumbles when you touch it.

e2.text: 2. How do you prepare the stems to braid them?

options.label: I moisten them a little and smooth them into parallel bundles.
options.successMsg: They remain flexible and manageable to turn without breaking.

options.label: I leave them in direct sunlight to dry.
options.failMsg: They become brittle. They are no longer suitable for twisting.

options.label: I group them without order to move faster.
options.failMsg: There's no internal tension. It dissolves easily.

e3.text: 3. Before braiding, you examine the fibers. What do you do?

options.label: Gently separate the longer, more flexible strands
options.successMsg: Good decision. That improves torque and strength.

options.label: Braids all as is
options.failMsg: There are thick fibers that get in the way. The rope is uneven.

options.label: You trim the uneven ends with a stone
options.failMsg: The stems will become shorter. The rope will become shorter and weaker.

options.label: You roll the bundles into themselves without separating anything
options.failMsg: They tangle poorly. It's hard to maintain the twisting speed.

e4.text: 4. You have two bundles of long grass. How do you begin to form the rope securely and durably?

options.label: You twist one bunch clockwise and one counterclockwise, then cross them over themselves
options.successMsg: The opposite twist creates tension and locks itself. Well done.

options.label: You roll both bundles in the same direction and join them together.
options.failMsg: They don't generate tension. They open at the slightest effort.

options.label: You make an initial knot and braid from there
options.failMsg: The knot slips and the rope won't hold.

e5.text: 5. You already have about 40 cm. How do you make it longer?

options.label: You add new stems to the rhythm of the turn, maintaining the tension
options.successMsg: Good technique. The rope can grow without losing strength.

options.label: I align the wet ends well and press them firmly until they adhere.
options.failMsg: It seems stable, but they separate when dried or pulled.

options.label: I insert them loosely, letting them blend on their own.
options.failMsg: It seems to work, but they slip with use.

e6.text: 6. How do you secure the connection points?

options.label: I wrap thin fibers over the joint while maintaining the twist
options.successMsg: Reinforces without crushing. Stays strong.

options.label: I compact the joints with a flat stone so they take up less space.
options.failMsg: You're accidentally weakening traction. Not a good idea.

options.label: I leave a loose lock in case I need to adjust it later.
options.failMsg: That end becomes a weak point. It slowly unwinds.

e7.text: 7. How do you test the strength of the rope?

options.label: I hang a medium-sized stone tied to the end
options.successMsg: It holds up well. Test passed.

options.label: I use it as a belt to test tension
options.failMsg: It stretches and loosens with movement.

options.label: I drag her along the ground with a stick
options.failMsg: Constant friction damages the fibers. Bad test.

e8.text: 8. The end unravels a little. What are you doing?

options.label: I make a simple knot and wrap it with more dry fibers
options.successMsg: Nice finish. The knot holds tight.

options.label: I wrap the end in fresh leaves
options.failMsg: Humidity loosens the fibers. It doesn't last long.

options.label: I leave it loose so I can use it later.
options.failMsg: It starts to fall apart without you noticing.

e9.text: 9. Where do you store the rope so that it lasts?

options.label: I hang it in a dry and ventilated place inside the shelter.
options.successMsg: Perfect. It remains intact.

options.label: I leave it in a cool, closed corner next to damp leaves.
options.failMsg: Accumulated moisture accelerates deterioration.

options.label: I leave it rolled up outside all night.
options.failMsg: The night humidity slowly softens it.

final.text: Success! You've created a rope over a meter long from long grass. Ready to tie, hang, or hunt. 🪢🌾

options.label: Start over
options.successMsg: You can try again whenever you want.

intro.text:
Has oído historias de piedras que reflejan. Quieres lograr algo impensable para tu 'época': verte a ti mismo.

Para fabricar un espejo prehistórico, deberás encontrar la piedra adecuada, trabajarla con precisión y paciencia, y pulirla con una mezcla abrasiva.

¿Podrás crear una superficie capaz de devolver tu imagen?

options.label: Empezar
options.successMsg: Empiezas la búsqueda del material ideal...

elegirMaterial.text: 1. Encuentras varios tipos de piedra. ¿Cuál eliges para el espejo?

options.label: Obsidiana
options.successMsg: Es naturalmente brillante. Ideal si se pule bien.

options.label: Granito
options.failMsg: Es rugoso y opaco. No sirve para reflejar.

options.label: Caliza blanca
options.failMsg: Demasiado clara y porosa. Refleja mal.

fragmentar.text: 2. Tienes un trozo de obsidiana. ¿Cómo lo fragmentas?

options.label: Golpeándolo con una piedra más dura
options.successMsg: Obtienes fragmentos afilados y planos. Perfecto.

options.label: Frotándolo contra el suelo
options.failMsg: No funciona. No se rompe adecuadamente.

seleccionarFragmento.text: 3. Tienes varios fragmentos de obsidiana. ¿Cuál eliges para pulir?

options.label: El más plano y oscuro
options.successMsg: Es el más adecuado para reflejar bien con pulido.

options.label: El más brillante pero curvo
options.failMsg: Distorsiona la imagen. Mala elección.

options.label: Uno con vetas blancas
options.failMsg: Interfiere con el reflejo.

prepararArena.text: 4. Necesitas un abrasivo para el pulido. ¿Qué usas?

options.label: Arena fina mezclada con agua
options.successMsg: Has creado una pasta abrasiva perfecta.

options.label: Ceniza y barro
options.failMsg: Esa mezcla ensucia, no pule.

options.label: Polvo de madera
options.failMsg: No tiene poder abrasivo.

options.label: Sobre una piedra plana
options.successMsg: Muy bien. Funciona como mesa de pulido natural.

options.label: Sobre una hoja grande
options.failMsg: Demasiado frágil. No soporta la fricción.

options.label: En la palma de tu mano
options.failMsg: Dañino y poco eficaz.

tecnicaPulido.text: 6. Has puesto arena sobre la piedra. ¿Cómo pulirás el fragmento?

options.label: Frotar en círculos con presión constante
options.successMsg: Desgasta lentamente la superficie. Bien hecho.

options.label: Golpearlo repetidamente
options.failMsg: Se rompe. Ya no sirve.

options.label: Frotar muy suave sin presión
options.failMsg: Insuficiente para pulir.

proteger.text: 7. Has creado tu espejo. ¿Cómo lo proteges?

options.label: Lo envuelvo en hojas y lo guardo en un hueco seco
options.successMsg: Perfecto. Así evitarás roturas o rayaduras.

options.label: Lo dejas sobre una roca al sol
options.failMsg: El calor lo fractura. Fin.

options.label: Lo entierras
options.failMsg: Se llena de polvo y se raya. Fin.

proteger2.text: 8. Has creado tu espejo. ¿Cómo lo proteges?

options.label: Lo envuelvo en hojas y lo guardo en un hueco seco
options.successMsg: Perfecto. Así evitarás roturas o rayaduras.

options.label: Lo dejas sobre una roca al sol
options.failMsg: El calor lo fractura. Fin.

options.label: Lo entierras
options.failMsg: Se llena de polvo y se raya. Fin.

proteger3.text: 9. Has creado tu espejo. ¿Cómo lo proteges?

options.label: Lo envuelvo en hojas y lo guardo en un hueco seco
options.successMsg: Perfecto. Así evitarás roturas o rayaduras.

options.label: Lo dejas sobre una roca al sol
options.failMsg: El calor lo fractura. Fin.

options.label: Lo entierras
options.failMsg: Se llena de polvo y se raya. Fin.

final.text: ¡Éxito! Has fabricado un espejo pulido con arena y piedra. Por primera vez, ves tu reflejo nítido. 🪞

options.label: Volver a empezar
options.successMsg: Puedes reiniciar el proceso cuando quieras.

intro.text:
You've found a good surface for painting on stone and want to decorate it with natural pigments.

To achieve vibrant, long-lasting colors, you need to source and prepare the materials well.

Can you create a drawing that will stand the test of time?

options.label: Begin
options.successMsg: You begin your search for the right pigment...

e1.text: 1. What do you use as natural pigments?

options.label: Clay
options.successMsg: Red ochre is abundant and long-lasting near the river.

options.label: Wet mud
options.failMsg: It does not dry or set well.

options.label: Ash
options.failMsg: It does not adhere to rock.

e2.text: 2. How do you prepare the pigment for painting?

options.label: Finely ground
options.successMsg: Good mix to apply on stone.

options.label: Coarse ground
options.failMsg: It does not adhere well or paint evenly.

options.label: Mixed with soil
options.failMsg: It is not suitable, it stains and peels off.

e3.text: 3. What agent do you mix with the pigment to make it adhere better?

options.label: Water
options.successMsg: Fluid but less durable paint.

options.label: Animal fat
options.successMsg: Strong and durable paint.

options.label: Saliva
options.failMsg: Low adhesion, comes off quickly.

e4.text: 4. Where will you paint your drawing?

options.label: Smooth, vertical limestone wall
options.successMsg: Perfect for the pigment to adhere.

options.label: Rough, porous rock with cracks
options.failMsg: The drawing is lost due to the texture.

options.label: Stone with wet moss
options.failMsg: It does not adhere well and wears out quickly.

options.label: Compacted sand wall
options.failMsg: It comes apart easily.

e5.text: 5. What technique do you use to paint?

options.label: Painting with pigment-stained fingers
options.successMsg: Allows control and detail.

options.label: Use a rudimentary paintbrush made from twigs
options.successMsg: More precision in details.

options.label: Throw dry pigment with your hand
options.failMsg: It gets lost and doesn't settle.

options.label: Clean the surface with dry leaves
options.successMsg: Surface ready and clean.

options.label: Rub with fine sand to remove dust
options.successMsg: Removes dust and dirt.

options.label: Scrape with a sharp stone
options.failMsg: Risk of damaging the surface.

e7.text: 7. What specific message do you paint so that other time travelers can understand where you come from?

options.label: A simple hourglass with visible grains marking the passage of time
options.failMsg: Not everyone will understand its meaning correctly, it is not such a modern invention.

options.label: A stylish compass with clear engraved directions
options.failMsg: It is misinterpreted with a normal wheel or drawing.

options.label: A schematic representation of a building with windows and a door
options.failMsg: The symbol may be confused or unrecognizable in this context.

options.label: An open book with pages and indicative lines of text
options.successMsg: A clear symbol of wisdom and learning that will endure.

e8.text: 8. How do you prevent the color of your paint from fading over time?

options.label: Applying natural oil to seal the pigment
options.successMsg: Preserves intensity and shine for longer.

options.label: Covering with wet mud to protect
options.failMsg: It damages and dulls natural colors.

options.label: Rubbing with stones to clean the surface
options.failMsg: It erases and damages the paint.

e9.text: 9. You want to add more colors to your drawing to make it more attractive. Where do you look for other pigments and how do you prepare them?

options.label: Crushed berries to create vivid pigments
options.successMsg: Berries provide bright colors, but are less durable.

options.label: Charcoal from burnt branches for dark details
options.successMsg: Intense black for details.

options.label: Try with ashes mixed with mud
options.failMsg: The result is greyish and unattractive.

final.text:
Success! You've created a rock drawing with various natural pigments that lasts over time.

Your art can tell stories for future generations.

options.label: Start over
options.successMsg: You can try another method whenever you want.

intro.text:
If you master ceramics, you will be able to create pots and containers ideal for storing water and other objects.

Now that you know how to control fire, it's time to build a kiln.

With the clay you have obtained for modeling, you can begin to make your own pot.

options.label: Begin
options.successMsg: You start by designing the oven…

e1.text: 1. To build the walls of the oven, what mix of materials is correct?

options.label: 20% water and 80% mud
options.successMsg: Correct, this ratio creates a mixture that is moist enough to mold but stable when dried, ideal for oven walls.

options.label: 20% mud and 80% water
options.failMsg: Too liquid, it is not suitable for building walls.

options.label: Mud without water
options.failMsg: Dry clay cannot be molded or bonded well; it needs water for cohesion and moldability.

e2.text: 2. What shape will the roof be?

options.label: Oval, curved from front to back.
options.successMsg: That's right, by curving the walls into an arch, the roof mud rests better and is less likely to collapse before drying, even with the help of branches.

options.label: The plan
options.failMsg: Straight walls do not help support the roof, increasing the risk of it sagging before drying.

options.label: Peak shape
options.failMsg: An open shape leaves a wider gap, which is difficult to cover without the roof collapsing.

e3mezcla.text: 3. You stack several layers of mud for the walls.

options.label: You stack clay in a U shape
options.successMsg: Filled

options.label: Decorate the oven to make it more visible.
Cool the oven structure.

e4.text: 4. Why do you build the chimney?

options.label: Extract the smoke and fan the fire
options.successMsg: Exactly, the chimney helps improve air circulation and combustion.

options.label: Decorate the oven to make it more visible.
options.failMsg: The fireplace has a technical function, not a decorative one.

options.label: Cool the oven structure.
options.failMsg: The chimney is not used for cooling, but for ventilation.

e5.text: 5. How should the pot be built? You begin by adding layers of clay.

options.label: You let each layer dry slowly.
options.successMsg: Drying each layer slowly helps prevent cracking and warping.

options.label: You add clay constantly
options.failMsg: Adding undried clay can ruin the structure.

options.label: You hit to compact
options.failMsg: No, hitting it too hard can break the pot before it dries.

e6.text: 6. How thick should the walls of the vessel be?

options.label: Between 1 and 2 cm.
options.successMsg: Enough to give it strength without being too heavy or prone to cracking.

options.label: Less than 0.5 cm
options.failMsg: Very thin, the walls can easily break during cooking or handling.

options.label: More than 5 cm
options.failMsg: Walls that are too thick take a long time to dry and may crack or warp.

options.label: Any thickness, it doesn't matter.
options.failMsg: Thickness directly affects the strength and quality of the vessel.

e7.text: 7. You light a fire in some branches and put the pot in. Why do you add a grate?

options.label: They hold the fuel up so that air can circulate underneath.
options.successMsg: The grate allows for good air circulation, keeping the fire lit and improving fuel efficiency.

options.label: They block the entrance to keep the heat in.
options.failMsg: Incorrect, blocking the entrance would prevent oxygen from entering and extinguish the fire.

options.label: They hold the vessel so that it does not touch the ground.
options.failMsg: No, the main function of the grate is to lift the fuel for air circulation.

e8.text: 8. It's time to open the oven

options.label: You open after 4 hours of cooling
options.successMsg: Correct, opening the kiln after it has cooled thoroughly prevents the vessel from cracking.

options.label: You open the oven after 2 hours to avoid breakages.
options.failMsg: It is not advisable to open the kiln so soon, as the vessel may break due to the sudden change in temperature.

options.label: You break the kiln to get the vessel out.
options.failMsg: No! Breaking the kiln is not a good idea and can damage the vessel.

options.label: You leave the door open before finishing to ventilate.
options.failMsg: Leaving the door open too early can cause uneven cooling and damage the vessel.

e9.text: 9. How do you know that the pot is well fired?

options.label: Immerse it in water to check that it holds liquids.
options.successMsg: Exactly, this way you can verify that the vessel is well fired and functional.

options.label: Breaking off a piece to check the color and texture.
options.failMsg: Breaking the vessel is neither necessary nor desirable for evaluating it.

options.label: Covering it with wet mud to prevent it from cracking.
options.failMsg: Covering with wet mud can cause damage or internal moisture.

final.text: Congratulations! Your pot has been fired correctly and can store water without leaking.

options.label: Start over
options.successMsg: You can try again whenever you want.

intro.text:
You are at the camp. Animal fat from a recent hunt lies nearby, and you've seen ashes left from burned wood.

Can you make soap like your ancestors did to clean skins and tools?

Use your knowledge and the right choices to craft usable natural soap.

options.label: Begin
options.successMsg: You gather ingredients and prepare for your primitive chemistry.

e1.text: 1. What do you need to make lye?

options.label: Burn hardwood and collect  white ash
options.successMsg: Hardwood ash contains potassium. That's the base for lye.

options.label: Boil grass until it blackens
options.failMsg: Grass doesn't yield lye. No alkali is produced.

options.label: Crush limestone into powder
options.failMsg: Limestone won’t dissolve. Not useful for soap.

e2.text: 2. How do you extract the lye?

options.label: Pour hot water over the ashes and let it drip slowly
options.successMsg: Slow percolation makes a strong alkaline liquid

options.label: Mix ash with oil and heat directly
options.failMsg: Heating ash with oil ruins both

options.label: Dry the ash and store it in a pouch
options.failMsg: Dry ash alone is useless

options.label: Filter it through sand and moss
options.failMsg: Sand doesn’t extract the alkali

e3.text: 3. You now have lye. What's next?

options.label: Heat animal fat until fully melted
options.successMsg: Melted fat allows proper saponification

options.label: Add water to fat and stir vigorously
options.failMsg: Cold chunks won’t mix

options.label: Cut the fat into chunks and mix cold
options.failMsg: Water dilutes the mix too early

options.label: Mix lye with crushed berries
options.failMsg: Berries may color it, but no soap is formed

e4.text: 4. How do you combine the ingredients?

options.label: Add lye slowly while stirring the hot fat
options.successMsg: Slow addition controls the reaction

options.label: Pour lye all at once and cover it
options.failMsg: Rapid addition breaks emulsion

options.label: Stir both cold in a wooden bowl
options.failMsg: No heat means no reaction

options.label: Let them sit together overnight
options.failMsg: Sitting without stirring won’t mix properly

options.label: Keep stirring until it traces and thickens like honey
options.successMsg: Stirring keeps it homogeneous

options.label: Cool it quickly with river water
options.failMsg: Cooling stops the process too early

options.label: Add sand to speed up hardening
options.failMsg: Sand makes it gritty

e6.text: 6. How do you harden the mixture?

options.label: Pour into molds made of bark or stone
options.successMsg: Natural molds let it set well

options.label: Leave it in the bowl to dry
options.failMsg: It sticks and breaks

options.label: Freeze it overnight
options.failMsg: Freezing ruins the soap

options.label: Wrap it in leaves tightly
options.failMsg: Leaf wrap keeps it moist too long

e7.text: 7. It's ready. How do you test it?

options.label: Rub a small piece with water on your hand
options.successMsg: Gentle foam shows success

options.label: Taste it to check bitterness
options.failMsg: Don’t taste lye! Unsafe!

options.label: Drop it in water to see if it floats
options.failMsg: Buoyancy means nothing here

e8.text: 8. The soap is formed. How do you dry it properly?

options.label: Let it rest in a dry, ventilated spot out of the sun
options.successMsg: Slow drying in the shade preserves quality

options.label: Expose it to direct sunlight to harden faster
options.failMsg: Sun cracks and degrades it

options.label: Store it in a sealed container right away
options.failMsg: Moisture stays trapped, promotes mold

options.label: Place it near the fire to speed it up
options.failMsg: Fire overheats and melts edges

e9.text: 9. How do you store the finished soap for future use?

options.label: Wrap it in dry leaves and store on a high shelf
options.successMsg: High and dry avoids pests and moisture

options.label: Keep it buried in damp earth
options.failMsg: Damp soil softens and ruins it

options.label: Store it in an animal skin pouch near the river
options.failMsg: Humidity causes it to dissolve over time

options.label: Leave it in an open bowl in the shelter
options.failMsg: Open air attracts insects and dirt

final.text: "You've created primitive soap. It lathers, cleans, and keeps your tools and skin fresh. Civilization starts with cleanliness. 🧼"

options.label: Start over
options.successMsg: You can try again whenever you want.
